Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Intergenerational Consequences of Incarceration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide new evidence on the effect of parental incarceration, addressing issues of statistical bias (endogeneity) with a quasi-experimental design that compares children whose parents, upon arrest, were randomly assigned to judges with differing propensities to incarcerate. Random assignment ensures that the differences in child outcomes can be attributed directly to parental incarceration (because the defendant was assigned to a harsh judge) versus a warning or probation (because the defendant was assigned to a lenient judge). This approach allows identification of the causal effect of parental imprisonment (and of incarceration length) for individuals with parents on the margin of incarceration.

The research design will be executed in two samples. For the first, the investigators will use historical prison rosters from the turn of the 20th century linked to the Censuses of 1890-1940 to estimates the very long-term income and criminal effects of parental incarceration. In the second, the investigators will use modern court records from Cook County to estimate the contemporary effect of parental incarceration on family structure, earnings, education, and criminal outcomes. Both sets of estimates will contribute to the current policy debate surrounding the long-term costs of both increased incarceration and longer sentence lengths, and to the academic understanding of intergenerational transmission of parental traits to their children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the effect of parental incarceration on long-term child outcomes. Previous research has compared the outcomes of children of incarcerated parents to the children of non-incarcerated parents, and typically found that the children of incarcerated parents have worse life outcomes such as adult income, adult crime, and mental health.

However, this comparison could reflect either the treatment effect of incarceration, or the fact that the children of incarcerated parents are already disadvantaged.

I overcome this challenge using data from Ohio, where criminal cases are randomly assigned to judges. Because the assignment is random, there are no pre-existing differences between the defendants assigned ot each judge. However, since judges differ in the share of defendants that they incarcerate, comparing the children of defendants assigned to high-incarcerating judges versus those assigned to low-incarcerating defendants recovers the causal effect of parental incarceration.

When I study this quasi-experiment, I find that parental incarceration reduces crime by the affected children, and improves their long-term socio-economic status as measuredy by the neighborhood of adult evidence. I find similar-sized effects for both maternal and paternal incarceration, and for black and white children. In contrast, the effects come almost entirely from children living in the poorest quarter of Ohio neighbhorhoods.

Possible mechanisms for the children include increased knowledge of the costs of crime, reduced subsequent exposure to crime (we document that incarceration reduces crime for both the defendant and their co-parent), and a more cohesive family environment (we find that parental incarceration reduces the number of half siblings for the child, and increases the number of full siblings). 

The paper documenting these effects is available on my website, http://www.samuel-norris.com.
